  • Style Guides

Style Guides

A front end styleguide is a set of standards for the writing and design of websites and applications. It is used to enforce styles/branding between designers and developers, as well as enforce object/module coding for multiple developer teams. Style guides can be displayed on a single page, or they can be broken into sub pages for larger projects and organization.

It is best practice to order a styleguide by the following list.

  • Branding (logos, colors, etc.)
  • Simple Objects (involving a single element tag)
  • Complex Objects (objects involving more than one element tag)
  • JS Modules (Objects that use JS for functionality)

Example

Below is an example of a simple single page style guide. Style guides are usually much lengthier with more branding, objects and modules.

Colors

#00afb2
#196c7d
#70c4c2
#60b989
#96d2a2
#313130
#4d4f4f
#999a9b
#e0e0e0

Text

This is a paragraph. The default stylings are inherited from the body. Paragraphs have a 20px margin-bottom. The primary font is Source Sans Pro.
